title: Cancer patient who was given just 18 months to live now has NO TRACE of the disease
text:
DEATH DODGING MIRACLE Cancer patient who was given just 18 months to live now has NO TRACE of the disease 
Medics told Bob Berry it was bad news after surgery, radiotherapy and chemotherapy all failed By LAUREN FRUEN Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A CANCER patient given just 18 months to live now has NO TRACE of the disease after testing a new wonder drug. 
Terminally ill Bob Berry was one of the first in the world to take part in the trial after being diagnosed with lung cancer three years ago. Manchester Evening News Bob Berry, 60, has been left with no trace of cancer after being one of the first in the world to take part in a new drugs trial Manchester Evening News 4 Bobpictured with his great niece and two great, great nieces, Maisie, Grace and Lydia 
The 60-year-old is just one of just 12 across the world to try the brand new drug, which cannot yet be named. 
It has left him with no apparent trace of tumour in his body. 
Bob, from Stockport, had tried surgery, radiotherapy and chemotherapy – all of which were unsuccessful. related stories TEEN ‘FAKED CANCER’ Cops probe claims 'cancer patient faked terminal illness so he could get free stuff including guitar and holiday from charity’ CANCER NET PLEAS Seven times as many cancer sufferers are turning to crowdfunding for treatment not available on the NHS 'helping each person live well' Theresa May to unveil plans for better post-treatment care for cancer patients 'THE CANCER ATE AWAY AT MY SPINE' Footballer who had a broken neck for three months is told his 'muscle pain' is cancer 'I WAS ADAMANT SHE WOULDN'T HAVE IT' Furious mum blasts school after daughter is given cervical cancer jab 'without consent' 
Medics told him he had around a year-and-a-half left to live, the Mirror Online reports. 
But Bob took part in the clinical trial using the drug which combines the drug with an immunotherapy treatment. Manchester Evening News Bob, pictured with Dr Matthew Krebs, said he couldn’t be more grateful for the treatment at The Christie one of the largest cancer treatment centres in Europe Manchester Evening News 4 Bob was one of just three people to take part in the trial at the hospital – and one of just 12 across the globe 
His consultant at The Christie, one of the largest cancer treatment centres in Europe, Dr Matthew Krebs, said: “Bob has had a phenomenal response to taking part in this clinical trial.” 
Mr Berry said: “Three years ago, I was given 12 – 18 months to live but I have already surpassed that and I feel well. 
“At the end of the day, this clinical trial at The Christie has extended my life and I couldn’t be more grateful.”
